{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3751701,"name":"Seth L","username":"SethL","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/ea666f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-29T17:56:28.611Z","cooked":"

I am trying to help my students install VS Code with WPILIB on a Mac computer. I have downloaded the Mac version from wpilib.org and installed it but continue to run into problems. Now it says that I need to install a JDK but I thought that was part of the download that I installed. If there are any specific tips that people have to get this running on a Mac, I would appreciate it.

I do see on wpilib.org “After installation, the installer opens the WPILib VS Code folder. Drag the VS Code application to the dock. Eject WPILibInstaller image from the desktop.” but I don’t remember seeing the application on the desktop, and what is the dock? I’m not a Mac person.

Could you describe the specific problem more thoroughly - maybe post a screenshot of the JDK error message? You might have set vscode up in a weird way, like trying to use an existing vscode app instead of letting wpilib install one.

Also, IDK why people are talking about the driver station app here, since the driver station app is separate from WPILib and not relevant to the original post. But just to clarify: the driver station cannot run on macOS, and it cannot run on virtualized arm64 Windows under an Apple Silicon host due to an outdated LabVIEW version. It might be able to run on emulated x64 Windows under an Apple Silicon host, but that would be slow, dangerous (you could move out of the VM and then enter/spacebar wouldn’t disable the bot), and a large hassle.

These replies are helpful and have me thinking. I am using VS Code to use Java to run the XRP robots. While it looks like I can get VS Code to work, and will try your suggestions, the driver station will be an issue. Maybe this should be its own question, but has anyone used the unofficial driver stations on a Mac?

I will try to update how things went once I see the kids next week.

Thanks for your help.

XRP doesn’t use the driver station. I drove mine around the house using my mac before I gave it to the team.

One aspect where an XRP project differs from a regular FRC robot project is that the code is not deployed directly to the XRP. Instead, an XRP project runs on your development computer and leverages the WPILib simulation framework to communicate with the XRP.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Programming the XRP

Writing a program for the XRP is very similar to writing a program for a regular FRC robot. In fact, all the same tools (Visual Studio Code, Driver Station, SmartDashboard, etc) can be used with th...
